comments.body: Should have a param to choose if we want 1.2 and 1.1 enabled

I don't think so, not enabling TLS 1.2 is just shooting yourself in the foot and I've never come across a reason why you would want to use an older protocol. Even if the server does not support 1.1/1.2 the TLS negotiation step will select the latest version that is common to both the client and the server.

We had some issues around this in enterprise environments with a mesh multiple devices/servers with different OSes and implementations of TLS
Giving the user of the module the option to force it not using 1.2 for example with the module instead of hacking the registry would be great
Maybe, I don't really want to make things easier for people to do insecure actions. This could be looked at in a separate PR and don't want to look into it right now.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +199,203 @@
    # Enable TLS1.1/TLS1.2 if they're available but disabled (eg. .NET 4.5)
    $security_protocols = [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol -bor [System.Net.SecurityProtocolType]::SystemDefault
    if ([System.Net.SecurityProtocolType].GetMember("Tls11").Count -gt 0) {
        $security_protocols = $security_protocols -bor [System.Net.SecurityProtocolType]::Tls11

comments.body: Are we keeping this just in case something outside of ansible[-collections] was using it?

Yep, technically it was added in 2.9 and without a deprecation period we can't remove it. Once this PR is in I'm hoping to create a copy of this util in ansible.windows and stop it relying on what's in ansible/ansible. The end goal is to move away from module utils being in ansible/ansible unless they are critical for all module execution, which this one is not.
